page.title: 16GALLOWHILL
page.content: From the tradition that in many parts of the country the gallows were erected on some small hill, the sight where the gallows of Crieff was erected has generally been considered to be that small mound near the cemetery, on the top of which grows a Lime tree. This part of Crieff is popularly known as the Gallowhill, and the district round about rejoices in the name of the Gallowhaugh. There is no proof, however, that this hill was a place of execution,and it has been suggested that the name Gallowhaugh in fact means the ford over the river, since there is a ford over the river Earn nearby.
